sn2.8:1.2: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.8:1.3: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.8:2.3: A sage who doesn’t give up sensual pleasures
sn2.8:2.4: is not reborn in a unified state.
sn2.8:3.1: If one is to do what should be done,
sn2.8:3.3: For the life gone forth when laxly led
sn2.8:3.4: just stirs up dust all the more.
sn2.8:4.1: A bad deed is better left undone,
sn2.8:4.2: for it will plague you later on.
sn2.8:4.3: A good deed is better done,
sn2.8:4.4: one that does not plague you.
sn2.8:5.1: When kusa grass is wrongly grasped
sn2.8:5.3: So too, the ascetic life, when wrongly taken,
sn2.8:7.1: That’s what the godling Tāyana said.
sn2.8:7.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.8:8.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
sn2.8:8.2: “Mendicants, tonight, the glorious godling Tāyana, formerly a religious founder, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.8:8.3: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha repeated the verses in full, adding:
sn2.8:14.1: “That’s what the godling Tāyana said. Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.
sn2.8:14.2: Mendicants, learn the verses of Tāyana!
sn2.8:14.5: These verses are beneficial and relate to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
